narrative.title: NIH Data Management and Sharing Plan

question.text: Types and amount of scientific data expected to be generated in the project

json.answer: The project 'req_abda76a627' aims to investigate anxiety symptoms and resilience processes in adolescents using longitudinal behavioral, clinical, and neurobiological assessments. The types of scientific data expected to be generated include demographic and clinical datasets, standardized anxiety and resilience scales, behavioral task data, physiological measures (e.g., heart rate variability), and derived summary variables. The estimated amount of scientific data is substantial due to the longitudinal multi-modal datasets collected across multiple time points, with physiological data and raw task files representing the largest portion of storage.

question.text: Scientific data that will be preserved and shared, and the rationale for doing so

json.answer: All scientific data generated from this project will be preserved and shared, including demographic and clinical datasets, standardized anxiety and resilience scales, behavioral task data, physiological measures, and derived summary variables. The rationale for sharing these data is to facilitate transparency, reproducibility, and advancement of research in adolescent mental health, anxiety, and resilience mechanisms. Sharing these data will enable other researchers to build upon our findings, explore new hypotheses, and contribute to the development of more effective interventions for adolescents.

question.text: Metadata, other relevant data, and associated documentation

json.answer: To facilitate interpretation of the scientific data, the following metadata, other relevant data, and associated documentation will be made accessible: study protocols, data collection instruments, data dictionary, README files, and any other documentation necessary for understanding the data collection process and the meaning of the variables.

section.title: Element 2: Related Tools, Software and/or Code

question.text: Element 2: Related Tools, Software and/or Code

json.answer: Specialized tools, software, and/or code are needed to access or manipulate shared scientific data. The specific tools and software required will include statistical analysis packages (e.g., R, Python libraries) for handling behavioral and physiological data, and potentially specialized software for analyzing neurobiological assessments. These tools and software can be accessed through public repositories or by contacting the research team.

Common data standards will be applied to the scientific data and associated metadata to enable interoperability of datasets and resources. The project will adhere to widely accepted standards in the field of psychology and neuroscience, including those for demographic data (e.g., NIH Toolbox), clinical assessments (e.g., standardized scales for anxiety and resilience), and physiological measures (e.g., standards for heart rate variability analysis). If applicable, any lack of consensus standards will be noted, and efforts will be made to align with emerging or de facto standards in the research community.

section.title: Element 4: Data Preservation, Access, and Associated Timelines

question.text: Repository where scientific data and metadata will be archived

json.answer: The scientific data and metadata arising from this project will be archived in a public repository that meets NIH standards for data sharing, such as the National Institutes of Health's National Library of Medicine (NLM) repositories or other approved data repositories like the Interuniversity Consortium for Political and Social Research (ICPSR).

question.text: How scientific data will be findable and identifiable

json.answer: The scientific data will be made findable and identifiable through the use of persistent unique identifiers, such as DOIs (Digital Object Identifiers), and standard indexing tools. This will enable easy location and access to the shared datasets.

question.text: When and how long the scientific data will be made available

json.answer: The scientific data will be made available no later than the time of an associated publication or the end of the performance period, whichever comes first. The data will remain available for a minimum of 10 years after the project's completion to allow for extended research and analysis by the broader scientific community.

section.title: Element 5: Access, Distribution, or Reuse Considerations

question.text: Factors affecting subsequent access, distribution, or reuse of scientific data

json.answer: While maximizing data sharing is a priority, factors such as informed consent, privacy, and confidentiality protections may limit subsequent access, distribution, or reuse of certain scientific data. Participants provided broad consent for de-identified data sharing, but any identifiable information will be protected in accordance with HIPAA regulations and IRB guidelines.

question.text: Whether access to scientific data will be controlled

json.answer: Access to the scientific data will not be controlled once they are deposited into a public repository, except as necessary to protect participant privacy and confidentiality. De-identified datasets will be made openly available for download.

question.text: Protections for privacy, rights, and confidentiality of human research participants

json.answer: To protect the privacy, rights, and confidentiality of human research participants, all shared data will be de-identified. This includes removal of direct identifiers (e.g., names, addresses) and indirect identifiers that could potentially reveal participant identities. Certificates of Confidentiality will be obtained to further safeguard against compelled disclosure of identifiable information.

section.title: Element 6: Oversight of Data Management and Sharing

question.text: Element 6: Oversight of Data Management and Sharing

json.answer: Compliance with this Data Management and Sharing Plan will be monitored and managed by the Principal Investigator (PI) in collaboration with the research institution's data management office. Regular oversight meetings will be held every six months to review data sharing progress, address any issues related to data preservation and access, and ensure that all shared data are properly de-identified and documented. The PI and the data management team will also conduct an annual review of the Plan's effectiveness and make necessary adjustments to maintain compliance with NIH policies on data sharing.
